data.text:
With superhero films still at a veryÂ high level of demand worldwide, it is interesting to considerÂ all content within the action genre and the demand for non-superhero films and series.Â Top Gun: Maverick, for instance, saw record levels of globalÂ demand and success - and is definitely one to watch in the upcomingÂ Global Demand Awards. TV series within the action genre, such asÂ The Walking Dead, as well as, more specifically, numerous anime series within the action genre, likeÂ Attack on Titan, have also seen some major success in terms of their level of global demand. This article will cover the global and regional demand for the action genre, as well as cover some possible reasons for why action films and series appear to be so well received by todayâs audience.

A Stand-Out Genre

It has beenÂ reported that action and adventure are, by quite a significant amount, the most popular movie genres within the United States and Canada over the past two decades. The chart below shows the ten films with the most global demand over last month. The action genre, particularly superhero films, dominates this list, withÂ Black Panther: Wakanda Forever at the top - just shy of 100 times more demand than the average film worldwide. The Marvel film, which ended the superhero franchiseâs fourth phase, reachedÂ new box office records in its opening weekend. This exceptional level of demand would most likely have influenced the spike in demand for the originalÂ Black Panther film, which reached 83.7 times more demand than the average film worldwide - making it third on this list, just after DC filmsâÂ Black Adam, which had 85 times more demand than the average film worldwide.

The above mentioned films, alongsideÂ Thor: Love and Thunder,Â The Batman, andÂ Spider-man: No Way Home, make up more than half of the films on this list, an indication of the longevity of the superhero genre. However, it is interesting to consider the other action films that make up this list. For instance,Â Top Gun: Maverick, released over six months ago, is still sitting at an exceptional level of demand.Â No Time To Die, the twenty-fifth film in theÂ James BondÂ franchise, is in a similar position, having been released in October last year and sitting comfortably at an exceptional level of demand - just under 65 times more demand than the average film worldwide. With this being said, whether it is the nostalgia of the filmsâ predecessors, or the star-studded casts, these action films have performed relatively similar to those within the superhero subgenre in terms of their global demand.

Other films on the above chart include Indian action films,Â RRR, with 74.6 times more demand than the average film worldwide, andÂ K.g.f: Chapter 2, with 62.4 times more demand than the average film worldwide. Both films, much like that ofÂ No Time To Die andÂ Top Gun Maverick, have remained at an exceptional level of demand even though they were released over seven months ago.

This Time Last Year

A similar lineup occurred over the month of November last year in terms of the most in demand films worldwide. The chart below shows the demand distribution for all films worldwide over November of 2021. The action genre made up a hundred percent of this list, with half of these being superhero films.Â Venom: Let There Be Carnage was at the top with 100.1 times more demand than the average film worldwide, whileÂ Eternals, another Marvel film, sat at 88 times more global demand than the average film.Â No Time To Die,Â Dune,Â Godzilla Vs. Kong,Â Free Guy, andÂ F9: The Fast SagaÂ were the top non-superhero films at this time - all with exceptional levels of demand.

Beyond the Superhero Genre

With the huge levels of demand for the superhero genre encompassing not just the demand distribution for the action genre, but the demand distribution forÂ all genres, it is important to consider how much demand there is for the action genre as a whole - and whether or not it is only held up by superhero films. This, however, may not be the case, if the chart below is anything to go by. Films within the action genre, including David LeitchâsÂ Bullet Train and Hindi action-adventureÂ BrahmÄstra Part One: Shiva, make up over half of the ten films with the most global demand outside of superhero films.

While it might be that these exceptional levels of demand that are apparent on the Â above chart could have been influenced by that of the superhero genre, the success of the films below points toward the high level of global demand for the action genre as a whole. The same, perhaps to a slightly lesser extent, can also be said for television series.

Demand for Action Series

The chart below shows the most in demand series over the month of November. TheÂ Game of ThronesÂ prequelÂ House ofÂ theÂ Dragon had 119.7 times more demand than the average series worldwide. Much likeÂ Game of Thrones itself, which had 117.3 times more demand than the average series worldwide, as well as a number of other series listed below, it is heavily fantasy-based. While all series on the chart below sit within the action genre, the heavier fantasy elements, as can be seen in anime,Â One Piece, and, to a different extent, AMC NetworksâÂ The Walking Dead - which both have well over 60 times more global demand than the average series worldwide - make for an interesting differentiation between the type of action films with the most demand and the type of action series with the most demand. While the most in demand non-superhero action films of last month had a lot more spy and military elements, the series shown in the chart below,Â excludingÂ The BoysÂ andÂ She-Hulk: Attorney At Law, include a lot more other-worldly themes, such as dragons, spaceships, and zombies.
